MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Estimated Assessments for Tax Purposes.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance the criteria for assessments of tax liability due from the commercial sector; whether these criteria are based on previous years' returns or on some other rational basis; whether such criteria are available in writing or whether in fact they are totally arbitrary in many cases; and whether there is an obligation on the Revenue Commissioners to explain the basis for their assessments in such cases.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: It is assumed that the Deputy's question relates to the making of estimated assessments for income tax and corporation tax purposes.

MainHeading.P: I am advised by the Revenue Commissioners that the amount of the profits of an undertaking is estimated by the inspector of taxes at the commencement of the tax year. The inspector bases his estimate on the best information available, if possible on the preceding year's income figure where it has been determined. However, if the information is not known the inspector would be expected to made his estimate by using his best judgment. The same would apply to the making of corporation tax assessments which would usually be raised about three months after the end of the company's accounting period, to allow for the statutory time limit for appeals before the due date for payment of the liability, or of the amount specified by the taxpayer.

With regard to explaining the basis of the amount assessed the taxpayer is entitled to lodge an appeal within the statutory time limit and to specify the amount of tax which he considers should be payable. In the ordinary way the question of the Revenue Commissioners being obliged to explain the basis of the estimate would not arise, since the taxpayer would know that he had not furnished the proper accounts and returns which would enable the liability to be accurately determined and that only he and his tax agents would be aware of the amounts of the taxable profits.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Discipline in Schools.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if guidelines on discipline were circulated to schools following the abolition of corporal punishment; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Following the abolition of corporal punishment in schools, a representative committee was set up “to consider the question of discipline in schools and to make recommendations”. The report of the committee will shortly be published and I shall be inviting the views of interested parties, particularly the parents' council, before formulating my response to the report.

I wish to place on the record of the House my Department's Circular 9/82, which announced the abolition of corporal punishment and contained a revised version of Rule 130 of the Rules for National Schools, which deals with school discipline.
Following is the circular:
Circular to Boards of Management and Principal Teachers of National Schools.
The Abolition of Corporal Punishment in National Schools.

The Minister for Education in pursuance of the Government commitment to the abolition of corporal punishment in schools, has, following consultations with representatives of teacher and managerial organisations, amended Rule 130 of the Rules for National Schools to read as follows:
Schools Discipline

130(1)Teachers should have a lively regard for the improvement and general welfare of their pupils, treat them with kindness combined with firmness and should aim at governing them through their affections and reason and not by harshness and severity. Ridicule, sarcasm or remarks likely to undermine a pupil's self-confidence should not be used in any circumstances.
(2)The use of corporal punishment is forbidden.
(3)Any teacher who contravenes sections (1) or (2) of this rule will be regarded as guilty of conduct unbefitting a teacher and will be subject to severe disciplinary action.

MainHeading.P: This amendment will have effect from 1 February, 1982. You are requested to bring this circular to the notice of all teachers in your school and of all future teachers appointed to the school.
L. Ó Laidhin,
Rúnaí
Eanáir, 1982
